title: 111_s2914
content: The Act is titled the "United States Employee Ownership Bank Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that between December 2007 and October 2009, payroll employment in the United States fell by 8.2 million, the manufacturing sector lost 5.6 million jobs between January 2000 and October 2009, and as of October 2009, fewer than 12 million workers were employed in the manufacturing sector. Additionally, the United States had a trade deficit of over $695 billion at the end of 2008, including a record-breaking deficit with China. Preserving and increasing decent paying jobs is a top priority, and providing support for employees to buy their own companies can help achieve this goal. The United States Employee Ownership Bank is proposed to be established within the Department of the Treasury to preserve and expand jobs in the United States, similar to the creation of the United States Export-Import Bank during the Great Depression to increase jobs through exports. The Act defines key terms such as "Bank" as the United States Employee Ownership Bank, "eligible worker-owned cooperative," "employee stock ownership plan," and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, it establishes the United States Employee Ownership Bank within the Department of the Treasury. The Secretary is required to establish the United States Employee Ownership Bank within 90 days to promote employee ownership and participation in company decision-making. The Bank will be managed by a Director appointed by the Secretary, who can hire necessary staff. The Bank is authorized to provide loans. The United States Employee Ownership Bank is authorized to provide loans for various purposes related to employee ownership, including purchasing companies, increasing employee ownership levels, and expanding operations to preserve employment. The United States Employee Ownership Bank requires that before providing loans, a business plan must show that at least 51% of the company is owned by an employee stock ownership plan or eligible worker-owned cooperative. The board of directors must be elected based on a one share to one vote basis. The United States Employee Ownership Bank requires that 51% of the company is owned by an employee stock ownership plan or worker-owned cooperative. Employees will vote according to IRS section 409(e) and receive company progress updates. A feasibility study by a third party must show the plan can generate enough profit to repay any loans from the Bank. The loan or loan guarantee from the Employee Ownership Bank must bear interest at a rate determined by the Secretary, with a maximum term of 12 years. SEC. 5. EMPLOYEE RIGHT OF FIRST REFUSAL BEFORE PLANT OR FACILITY CLOSING. Section 3 of the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act is amended to include provisions for employee stock ownership plans or eligible worker-owned cooperatives. If an employer orders a plant or facility closing, they must offer employees the opportunity to purchase the plant or facility through an employee stock ownership plan or eligible worker-owned cooperative. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act is amended to include provisions for employee stock ownership plans or eligible worker-owned cooperatives. If an employer orders a plant closing, employees must be given the opportunity to purchase the plant or facility at fair market value determined by an independent third party. The cost of the appraisal can be shared between the employer and employees. Exemptions apply if the employer retains assets for business continuation in the US or relocates the business to another plant. Employees must be given the opportunity to purchase a plant or facility at fair market value if an employer orders a plant closing. Exemptions apply if the employer retains assets for business continuation in the US or relocates the business to another plant. Before the end of the 90-day period, the Secretary of the Treasury must implement regulations for the Act, including ensuring the Bank's safety and soundness and preventing competition with commercial financial institutions. Additionally, there is a provision for community reinvestment credit. SEC. 7. COMMUNITY REINVESTMENT CREDIT. This section amends the Community Reinvestment Act to allow financial institutions to support employee stock ownership plans and worker-owned cooperatives. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary to carry out the Act includes $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, with additional funds as needed thereafter.
